--- title: "Take-home Exercise 3: Prototyping Modules for Geospatial Analytics Shiny Application (not done)" format: html: code-fold: true code-summary: "Show the code" execute: freeze: true warning: false editor: visual date: "March 16, 2024" --- # 1 Overview ## 1.1 Background ## 1.2 Objectives ## 1.3 The Task ## 1.4 The Data ## 1.5 Installing and Loading R Packages In this exercise, the following R packages would be used: Then, to install and/or load the R packages, we can use p_load() from the pacman package. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(sf, tidyverse, tmap, SpatialAcc, ggplot2, ggstatsplot, spDist, spNetwork, reshape2) ``` ::: # 2 Data Preparation (Geospatial) ## 2.1 Data Import Letâ€™s begin by introducing and preparing our geospatial data set in R! To import geospatial data, we will be using st_read() from the sf package. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz2019 <- st_read("data/MasterPlan2019SubzoneBoundaryNoSeaGEOJSON.geojson") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz2019 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Simple feature collection with 332 features and 2 fields Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XY, XYZ Bounding box: xmin: 103.6057 ymin: 1.158699 xmax: 104.0885 ymax: 1.470775 z_range: zmin: 0 zmax: 0 Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 First 10 features: Name 1 kml_1 2 kml_2 3 kml_3 4 kml_4 5 kml_5 6 kml_6 7 kml_7 8 kml_8 9 kml_9 10 kml_10 Description 1

Let's visualize how it looks like using plot() and st_geometry() from the sf package. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(st_geometry(mpsz2019)) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(st_geometry(eldercare_services)) ``` ::: ## 2.2 Data Pre-Processing ### 2.2.1 Dropping Z-dimension ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz <- st_zm(mpsz2019) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ### 2.2.2 Resolving invalid geometries ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} length(which(st_is_valid(mpsz) == FALSE)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 6 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} length(which(st_is_valid(eldercare_services) == FALSE)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz <- st_make_valid(mpsz) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} length(which(st_is_valid(mpsz) == FALSE)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ::: ### 2.2.3 Handling missing values ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz[rowSums(is.na(mpsz)) != 0, ] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Simple feature collection with 0 features and 2 fields Bounding box: xmin: NA ymin: NA xmax: NA ymax: NA Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 [1] Name Description geometry <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} eldercare_services[rowSums(is.na(eldercare_services)) != 0, ] ``` ::: eldercare_services[rowSums(is.na(eldercare_services %>% select(11,19))) != 0, ] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Simple feature collection with 0 features and 18 fields Bounding box: xmin: NA ymin: NA xmax: NA ymax: NA Projected CRS: SVY21 [1] OBJECTID ADDRESSBLO ADDRESSBUI ADDRESSPOS ADDRESSSTR ADDRESSTYP [7] DESCRIPTIO HYPERLINK LANDXADDRE LANDYADDRE NAME PHOTOURL [13] ADDRESSFLO INC_CRC FMEL_UPD_D ADDRESSUNI X_ADDR Y_ADDR [19] geometry <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names) ``` ::: ::: ### 2.2.4 Changing and verifying CRS ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} st_crs(mpsz) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Coordinate Reference System: User input: WGS 84 wkt: GEOGCRS["WGS 84", DATUM["World Geodetic System 1984", ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563, LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]]], PRIMEM["Greenwich",0, ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433]], CS[ellipsoidal,2], AXIS["geodetic latitude (Lat)",north, ORDER[1], ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433]], AXIS["geodetic longitude (Lon)",east, ORDER[2], ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433]], ID["EPSG",4326]] ``` ::: ::: The mpsz data set is not in our desired coordinate system (SVY21; EPSG: 3414). Hence, we need to reproject it. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} st_crs(eldercare_services) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Coordinate Reference System: User input: SVY21 wkt: PROJCRS["SVY21", BASEGEOGCRS["SVY21[WGS84]", DATUM["World Geodetic System 1984", ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563, LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]], ID["EPSG",6326]], PRIMEM["Greenwich",0, ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]]], CONVERSION["unnamed", METHOD["Transverse Mercator", ID["EPSG",9807]], PARAMETER["Latitude of natural origin",1.36666666666667, ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433], ID["EPSG",8801]], PARAMETER["Longitude of natural origin",103.833333333333, ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433], ID["EPSG",8802]], PARAMETER["Scale factor at natural origin",1, SCALEUNIT["unity",1], ID["EPSG",8805]], PARAMETER["False easting",28001.642, LENGTHUNIT["metre",1], ID["EPSG",8806]], PARAMETER["False northing",38744.572, LENGTHUNIT["metre",1], ID["EPSG",8807]]], CS[Cartesian,2], AXIS["(E)",east, ORDER[1], LENGTHUNIT["metre",1, ID["EPSG",9001]]], AXIS["(N)",north, ORDER[2], LENGTHUNIT["metre",1, ID["EPSG",9001]]]] ``` ::: ::: The eldercare_services data set does not have the correct EPSG code (3414). Hence, we must reassign the EPSG code to it. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz_sf <- st_transform(mpsz, 3414) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} eldercare <- st_set_crs(eldercare_services, 3414) ``` ::: ### 2.2.6 Extraction of relevant columns #### 2.2.6.1 Extraction of subzone and planning area names in mpsz_sf For subzone: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz_sf <- mpsz_sf %>% rowwise() %>% mutate(SUBZONE= str_extract(`Description`, "SUBZONE_N (.*?)")) %>% ungroup() ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz_sf$SUBZONE <- str_remove_all(mpsz_sf$SUBZONE, "<.*?>|SUBZONE_N") ``` ::: For planning area: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz_sf <- mpsz_sf %>% rowwise() %>% mutate(PLAN_AREA= str_extract(`Description`, "PLN_AREA_N (.*?)")) %>% ungroup() ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz_sf$PLAN_AREA <- str_remove_all(mpsz_sf$PLAN_AREA, "<.*?>|PLN_AREA_N") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz_sf ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Simple feature collection with 332 features and 4 fields Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 2667.537 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33 Projected CRS: SVY21 / Singapore TM # A tibble: 332 Ã— 5 Name Description geometry SUBZONE PLAN_AREA * 1 kml_1 "
% select(11,19) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} eldercare ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Simple feature collection with 133 features and 1 field Geometry type: POINT Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 14481.92 ymin: 28218.43 xmax: 41665.14 ymax: 46804.9 Projected CRS: SVY21 / Singapore TM First 10 features: NAME 1 Yuhua Senior Activity Centre 2 THK SAC @ Kaki Bukit 3 THK SAC @ Boon Lay 4 PEACE-Connect Senior Activity Centre@5 5 THK SAC @ Beo Crescent 6 Silver ACE @ Bukit Merah 7 Lions Befrienders Senior Activity Centre @ Tampines Blk 499C 8 Care Corner Senior Activity Centre (WL569) 9 Fei Yue Senior Activity Centre (Bukit Batok Branch) 10 COMNET Senior Activity Centre @ 182 Rivervale Crescent geometry 1 POINT (16614.08 36639.12) 2 POINT (38803.81 35098.78) 3 POINT (14481.92 36357.61) 4 POINT (31505.35 31853.52) 5 POINT (27218.35 30135.49) 6 POINT (27278.94 29350.17) 7 POINT (41665.14 37956.92) 8 POINT (23147.94 45761.17) 9 POINT (18820.58 36396.32) 10 POINT (36446.37 41376.9) ``` ::: ::: ### 2.2.7 Creating hexagon data (******** NEED TO WORK HERE*****) ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: # 3 Data Preparation (Distance Matrix) The first step to dealing with our aspatial data is to import it into our R environment. To do so, we can use read_csv() from the readr package. ## 3.1 Computing Distance Matrix ### 3.1.1 Converting from sf data.table to SpatialPolygonsDataFrame ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz_sp <- as(mpsz_sf, "Spatial") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz_sp ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` class : SpatialPolygonsDataFrame features : 332 extent : 2667.537, 56396.44, 15748.72, 50256.33 (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) crs : +proj=tmerc +lat_0=1.36666666666667 +lon_0=103.833333333333 +k=1 +x_0=28001.642 +y_0=38744.572 +ellps=WGS84 +towgs84=0,0,0,0,0,0,0 +units=m +no_defs variables : 4 names : Name, Description, SUBZONE, PLAN_AREA min values : kml_1,

::: ### 3.1.3 Labelling column and row headers of a distance matrix ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sz_names <- mpsz_sf$SUBZONE ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} colnames(dist_matrix) <- paste0(sz_names) rownames(dist_matrix) <- paste0(sz_names) ``` ::: ### 3.1.4 Pivoting distance value by SUBZONE name ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} head(distPair) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` origin dest dist 1 DEPOT ROAD DEPOT ROAD 0.000 2 BUKIT MERAH DEPOT ROAD 1116.522 3 CHINATOWN DEPOT ROAD 3917.381 4 PHILLIP DEPOT ROAD 4474.975 5 RAFFLES PLACE DEPOT ROAD 4727.007 6 CHINA SQUARE DEPOT ROAD 4271.839 ``` ::: ::: ### 3.1.5 Updating intra-zonal distances ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} distPair %>% filter(dist > 0) %>% summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` origin dest dist DEPOT ROAD : 331 DEPOT ROAD : 331 Min. : 173.8 BUKIT MERAH : 331 BUKIT MERAH : 331 1st Qu.: 7149.5 CHINATOWN : 331 CHINATOWN : 331 Median :11890.0 PHILLIP : 331 PHILLIP : 331 Mean :12229.4 RAFFLES PLACE: 331 RAFFLES PLACE: 331 3rd Qu.:16401.7 CHINA SQUARE : 331 CHINA SQUARE : 331 Max. :49894.4 (Other) :107906 (Other) :107906 ``` ::: ::: From the results, we can see that the minimum distance is 173.8m. Next, a constant distance of 50m is added into the intra-zones distance. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} distPair$dist <- ifelse(distPair$dist == 0, 50, distPair$dist) ``` ::: The code below can be used to check the result data.frame. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} distPair %>% summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` origin dest dist DEPOT ROAD : 332 DEPOT ROAD : 332 Min. : 50 BUKIT MERAH : 332 BUKIT MERAH : 332 1st Qu.: 7097 CHINATOWN : 332 CHINATOWN : 332 Median :11864 PHILLIP : 332 PHILLIP : 332 Mean :12193 RAFFLES PLACE: 332 RAFFLES PLACE: 332 3rd Qu.:16388 CHINA SQUARE : 332 CHINA SQUARE : 332 Max. :49894 (Other) :108232 (Other) :108232 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} distmat_km <- as.matrix(dist_matrix/1000) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: # 4 Modelling and Visualizing Accesssibility using Hansen Method (requires hexagon) ## 4.1 Computing Hansen's accessibility (requires hexagon) ::: {.cell} ::: ## 4.2 Visualizing Hansen's accessibility ### 4.2.1 Extracting map extend (requires hexagon) ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ### 4.3 Statistical graphic visualization
